comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content: [upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/41/Loop_Head_-_g...] This photograph from Wikipedia isn't credited to an author and it appears in a blog by Liam Herringshaw in memory of the late Professor Trevor Elliott of Liverpool University who studied the cliffs here and at Ballybunion, in Kerry. The formation is described as a Carboniferous Turbidite. But Samson could have pushed out the rock before Delilah cut his hair.

comment.author: 90124154@N00
comment._content:
Sampson Island (or Samson's Island, or the Isle of St. Samson) is important in the Tristan legends.  That is where Tristan fought Morholt.  It's usually assumed that the island in question is the St. Samson's Isle of the Scilly Islands, but the description of the battle states that the combatants crossed to the island with their horses and gear and their comrades watched from a nearby shore - both unlikely on the Scilly Samson's.  

Since St. Samson is also reputed to have traveled to Ireland and either founded or revived a monastery, it's possible that he had an eponymous Irish island as well, though whether or not this is it is likely irrelevant   The story of Tristan & Isolde had a rebound in popularity in the late 19th century with the Wagner opera's premiere in 1865

My guess is that the local innkeepers/chamber of commerce/tourist board expropriated the legend and put up the Samson's Island sign to offer something to the opera loving Tristan fans.  

Purely (and cynically) a guess.
